# Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge Warden's Residence

| locmapin                = Alabama#USA
| built                   = 1941
| architect               = Grammer and Holland
| architecture            = stone, side gable
| added                   = May 17, 2010
| area                    =
| refnum                  = 10000258
| designated_other1_name  = Alabama Register of Landmarks and Heritage
| designated_other1_abbr  = ARLH
| designated_other1_color = #CDE5B2
| designated_other1_link  = Alabama Register of Landmarks and Heritage
| designated_other1_date  = February 2, 2001
}}
The '''Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge Warden's Residence, also known simply as Warden's Residence''', is a house in Triana, Alabama. It was built in 1941 by the Civilian Conservation Corps to serve as the residence of the warden of Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge. It was used by the warden until 1947, and in 1950, the local clinic serving African Americans in the area was moved into the house.  The clinic was later desegregated, and operated until 1990.  Today, the house is the center of a  park run by the town.
The building was listed on the Alabama Register of Landmarks and Heritage in 2001 and the National Register of Historic Places in 2010.  The listing included two contributing buildings on .
